Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Systematic Review of Studies to Improve Success in STEM Degree Programs of Hispanic Students Matriculating through Two-year Institutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a comprehensive synthesis of existing primary studies of transfer of Hispanic students from 2-year to 4-year institutions. Although substantial research has identified cultural and socioeconomic challenges facing Hispanic students in higher education, much less is known about Hispanic STEM students, and virtually no large scale studies have studied Hispanic STEM transfer students specifically. The study will identify patterns of successes and failures of Hispanic STEM transfer students and identify factors related to effectiveness of interventions to promote transfer, retention, and graduation of Hispanic STEM undergraduates. This synthesis will contribute to achieving PCAST recommendations for a million more STEM graduates by 2018, supporting efforts within federal agencies to improve the success of under-represented students in STEM, and increasing knowledge about what works based on a comprehensive synthesis of published research.

The research question guiding this systematic review is: What student and contextual characteristics and interventions have prior studies identified as supporting successful transfer and STEM bachelor's degree completion of Hispanic students who matriculate at two-year institutions? A preliminary scoping review of several databases yielded 1,328 potential sources to inform this systematic review to develop a framework specific to Hispanic STEM transfer students. Most retention and transfer work has been based on a framework of social integration. A good example of this framework is: Vincent Tinto, "Leaving college: Rethinking the causes and cures of student attrition," Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1993. This perspective has been found by some to be less relevant to Hispanic students. An example is the work of Tatiana Melguizo, "Are community colleges an alternative path for Hispanic students to attain a bachelor's degree?" Teachers College Record, Volume 110, No. 12, 2008.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research has synthesized all of the relevant prior work regarding Latinx students matriculating through two-year to four-year institutions and completing engineering bachelor?s degrees. We chose to study this student group for several reasons. First, recent reports from National Academies argue for leveraging 2-year to 4-year transfer to help meet STEM workforce demand. Second, Latinx students disproportionately graduate from 2-year institutions with the intention to transfer and pursue a bachelor?s degree at a 4-year institution. In quantitative terms, 45% of Latinx STEM students who pursued higher education in 2012 attended public, 2-year colleges. Third, Latinx students are the largest of minority populations underrepresented in STEM fields. Separately studying underrepresented groups in STEM is important because access to higher education and transfer patterns differ between student groups.

We used systematic review methodology to identify, review, select, and synthesize articles. Systematic review is a set of methodologies to identify relevant primary studies (e.g., journal articles, technical reports, dissertations, conference papers) from multiple sources and synthesize results from these studies. A systematic review can provide an overview of individual studies, illuminating both what is known and not yet known about the focus of the review. One main focus of our research was on identifying studies regarding interventions designed to support success of Latinx students matriculating at 2-year institutions, as well as their successful transfer to 4-year institutions, particularly for STEM majors.

We considered the studies in terms of assets-based and deficit-based perspectives. A deficit-based perspective views a student as somehow deficient in skills or capital to navigate higher education, such as inadequate high school preparation or family and work commitments outside of school that conflict with time required to succeed in higher education. Deficit-based interventions focus on ?fixing? the student or eliminating the problem. Assets-based approaches focus on the unique skills and assets that underrepresented students bring to higher education, for example, navigating systems and having strong community and family ties.

A main finding from this project is the surprisingly small number of relevant studies, especially given the importance of improving success of Latinx students and the length of time during which the problem has been repeatedly emphasized. We screened over 4,000 abstracts of studies published since 1980 and identified only 170 relevant studies. Most of the studies we found focused on Latinx student success at 2-year institutions, while only a few addressed transfer students or Latinx STEM student success. We divided these 170 studies into two groups for analysis: those describing interventions (such as programs and services for students) and those describing factors (such as student and institution characteristics).

We found a wide range of intervention, including: mentoring, counseling, advising, study groups, tutoring, scholarships, orientations, career services, undergraduate research, articulation agreements, and transfer programs. Individually, these studies report positive influences on student success outcomes, including 2-year and 4-year graduation, transfer to a 4-year institution, retention, and success in individual courses. In general, interventions with strong evidence bases in 4-year, primarily-white institutions seem to also work for Latinx students in 2-year institutions and transfer students, with appropriate modification. However, the studies were primarily designed from an implicit or explicit deficit-minded perspective.

Many of the factor studies took an implicit deficit-based approach in exploring student characteristics alone, while some studies explicitly sought to identify assets Latinx students bring to higher education. However, our review also identified multiple factors that institutions can apply to transform their practices and policies to enable an assets-based focus on Latinx students. All of the factor studies contributed to the conclusion that quality interactions with peers and staff support Latinx STEM transfer students? success. These include (i) strengthening staff interactions with students; (ii) promoting supportive peer interactions (e.g., study groups, living-learning communities, and peer mentors); (iii) improving the cultural climate for all students; (iv) improving quality of, access to, and student awareness of advising, counselling, and mentoring services; and (v) increasing availability and improving the quality of programs and services that support academic integration.

Our review also identified wide-ranging issues for Latinx STEM transfer student success beyond STEM content. This may point to an opportunity to include the populations targeted by interventions in the design of those interventions. Including students in the design of interventions is more likely to result in holistic, asset-based approaches that support Latinx student success.
